awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Accelerating New Environmental Workskills (ANEW)
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of Maine, located in Orono, ME, will support the training 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021.  The REU Site theme implements convergent thinking to solve complex, interdependent problems in human, animal and environmental health (One Health). Faculty mentors represent the Schools of Food and Agriculture, Marine Sciences, Biology and Ecology, Wildlife, Forestry, Economics and Climate Change. REU students conduct research on topics such as ecology/health of wild animals (e.g. wild turkey, moose, seals) in relationship to livestock/human health and explore relevant environmental policy. REU students also participate in workshops on mentor-mentee relationships, goal-setting, research design/ethics; data collection, analysis and interpretation; and communication and collaborative problem solving skills. Students present their results at an annual One Health symposium. The REU will strive to enroll at least 50% under-represented students in STEM (African Americans, Hispanics, American Indians, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians or Other Pacific Islanders), veterans, and early-career (freshmen to juniors, community college) or first-generation college students. Students apply online and applications are immediately reviewed by the leadership team, with mentor assignment and discussion of project topic prior to program start.

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program.  Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present results of their work at scientific conferences. Each student will be paired with a secondary broader impacts mentor, who will share the relevance of One Health research to ?real world? problems and foster career options in their field.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (DBI) will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting https://nsfa.umaine.edu/one-health/REU, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Anne Lichtenwalner at anne.lichtenwalner@maine.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Kristina Cammen at kristina.cammen@maine.edu). This award is supported by DBI in the Directorate for Biological Sciences (BIO) and the EPSCoR program in the Office of Integrative Activities (OIA).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ongoing rapid environmental and land use changes, alongside increases in infectious and non-infectious disease on a global scale highlight the need for training students in an interdisciplinary approach that considers disease dynamics at the intersection of human, animal, and environmental health. From 2019 to 2022, the Research Experience for Undergraduates Site: Accelerating New Environmental Workskills (REU ANEW) offered such training to 30 undergraduate students through a summer internship program at the University of Maine. During their internship, diverse undergraduate student cohorts developed critical research and thinking skills that will empower them to tackle complex, interdisciplinary problems related to One Health. REU ANEW students completed independent research projects and participated in weekly professional development workshops to build skills in problem solving, research design, data analysis, and communication. The student internship experience was shaped by faculty, practitioner, and graduate student mentorship, as well as cohort-based peer-to-peer support.

REU ANEW participants represented social and academic diversity along many spectra. Participants came from diverse undergraduate degree programs throughout the United States, representing 17 states and Puerto Rico. Half of the participants were from non-PhD granting institutions and a third of participants were first-generation college students. Over a third of the REU ANEW participants were from groups historically underrepresented in the fields of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), and the majority of participants were female. Through dedicated diverse recruitment practices, REU ANEW thus offered research opportunities to many students who may not have had access to these opportunities at their home institution and contributed to broadening participation in STEM fields. Following their participation in the REU ANEW program, over a third of the participants who have since completed their undergraduate degrees have entered STEM graduate degree programs and many others are working in STEM-related industries.

During their summer internships, REU participants pursued diverse research topics that spanned the natural and social sciences, from lab to field to policy, from marine to terrestrial species. Their research findings contribute to our understanding of the environmental, biological, and social drivers of disease dynamics and other health issues. Their research also has broader impacts in its ability to meaningfully inform the approaches we take through public policy or other human behaviors to improve environmental, animal, and human health outcomes. REU students learned about and worked to implement these applications of their research in collaboration with a “broader impacts” mentor from outside of academia. Complementary to their primary faculty research mentor and graduate student bench mentors, the role of the broader impacts mentors was to share the relevance of One Health research to real-world problems and foster student interest in diverse career options in their field.

Science communication was a strong focus of the professional development activities and practice that REU participants engaged with throughout their summer program. Students gained experience with written, graphical, and oral communication targeted for diverse audiences, and with the iterative practice of giving and receiving feedback on communication products. At the midpoint of their programs, REU participants published blog posts about their research and lessons learned thus far. At the conclusion of the program, students presented their research findings and their broader implications at a One Health ANEW research symposium, attended by University faculty, staff, and students, as well as managers, stakeholders, and other members of the general public. During and after their summer internship, several students have also presented their research at regional and national scientific conferences, broadly disseminating their findings to diverse audiences.
